captions.text:
Ray, you build a baseball field
in the middle of nowhere...

- Your daughter's turned into a space case.
- Get your hands off her!

- Is she all right?
- I don't know.

- Is she breathing?
- Should I get the car?

- What have we got here?
- She fell.

- This child's choking to death.
- Get her up.
Hot dog. Stuck in her throat.

She'll be turning handsprings
before you know it.
Oh, my God. You can't go back.

- You can't go back.
- It's all right.
I best be getting on home...

...before Alicia begins to think
I got a girlfriend.
Win one for me one day, will you, boys?
When did these ballplayers get here?

title: Field of Dreams (6/9) Movie CLIP - Doc Saves Karin (1989) HD

comments.text:
Ray Kinsella: Fifty years ago, for five minutes you came within... y-you 
came this close. It would KILL some men to get so close to their dream and 
not touch it. God, they'd consider it a tragedy.
Dr. Archibald "Moonlight" Graham: Son, if I'd only gotten to be a doctor 
for five minutes... now *that* would have been a tragedy.﻿

comments.text:
What a fine book, and I read it long before it became a movie.  The movie 
is really good, except with the interjection of Ray's wife being a 
liberal-activist.  As James Earl Jones' character says, "Everything about 
America is baseball."  It ain't about some dull-witted screen writer 
inserting an ass-wipe, liberal character.  IT IS ABOUT BASE-BALL!﻿

comments.text:
This is a 3, not 4,  Star movie for two reasons:  The casting of Amy

comments.author: jwmellott

comments.text:
How else do you suggest they establish who Terrence Mann is and what his 
cultural significance was in one scene or less? In the book it was J.D. 
Salinger, a real person.
Oh, and your annoyance at stereotyping doesn't work because this is where 
Amy Madigan's character is from. She IS one of the "rural folk" and so are 
all of the people who SUPPORT her in that scene and in fact don't go along 
with the people who thought the books were "pornography."
Besides, that "Nazi cow" line is one of my mom's favourites. :p
comments.author: zammmerjammer

comments.text:
+DFDalton1962 The fly-over folks aren't that?  Oh.  Ok.  ;-)  

(I actually agree. . .it didn't really have anything to do with the story, 
other than perhaps maybe cues/causes from your loved ones (the 60's) can 
connect you to your dreams (yes, I'm reaching).  But, it's not enough to 
downgrade this classic to a 3 star)
comments.author: Christopher Stuart

comments.text:
I agree on both points. An otherwise magical movie is tarnished because 
Hollywood, even back in the 80s, simply couldn't resist the inclusion of a 
stereotypical and cartoonish portrayal of rural folk in "flyover country" 
as intolerant, uneducated, morally bigoted rubes to be put in their 
place by the college-educated outsider hero. They could have at least been 
a little more subtle about it. It was an unnecessary and cringeworthy scene 
which I fast-forward through whenever I watch the movie. And Amy Madigan 
did have a very irritating voice, though that worked somewhat better for 
her in "Uncle Buck"..
comments.author: DFDalton1962

comments.author: divisioneight

comments.text:
I think it goes without saying I get a bit worked up thinking about my dad 
in the movie's final scene, but this one also strikes a particular chord 
with me: My mom had my twin brother and I when she was 16. Her lifelong 
dream was to become a doctor, but she put it off to raise my brother and 
me. She started med school at the age of 37. Something about the gravel and 
Archie turning into Doc....oh man.
comments.author: CanadianGuitarist

comments.author: Daniel Freeman

comments.text:
I haven't seen this movie in years, but consider this (and I am saying this 
as a fan only): 1) On the field he may "know" he's a doctor in his later 
years, but he hasn't seen the event up close and even if he did he may not 
yet have the know how and 2) Notice when he crosses off the field he has 
his medical kit so in the event he needed something from he'd have it. He 
didn't have access to it on the field as his younger self.
comments.author: Tigerman1138

comments.text: Ray couldn't have taken Karen out onto the field?!
comments.author: Wesley Grisum

comments.text:
That's what SalasSnake was pointing out. He dies before the Heimlich was 
invented, SO that's why he performs something different.
comments.author: Uriel Reyes

comments.text:
In case you didn't notice, he didn't perform the Heimlich maneuver. That 
involves using your fist and hand to perform abdominal thrusts in order 
expel air from the lungs to dislodge a blockage from the throat. He slapped 
her on the back. That technique has been around since before you were born. 
Any questions?
comments.author: TheSurfKings

comments.text:
nice accuracy; Doc Graham dies in 1972, 2 years before the Heimlich 
maneuver was invented.

comments.text:
This is as close as you get to the perfect Movie and this is the best scene

comments.author: McMoidart

comments.text:
I've been to this field with my son and it IS magic. I stood where Burt 
Lancaster stood and sat where Kevin Costner sat. We stood where Kevin 
Costner and his "Dad" had a catch and we had a catch. When other people (of 
all ages) showed up from all over the states they joined us in a hitting 
and catching game like we knew each other for years. There were no fees, 
suspicion, envy, hesitation, shyness or feeling foolish... just an 
unexplainable joy and sharing. No fooling. See for yourself.
comments.author: PatrolOfficer161

comments.text:
Killer scene with one of the true legends of his craft, the late Burt
